messages.content: Text created/updated with CEFR level A2

Text saved: The Hunger Games are a game that happens every year.  
A game means people do something to win or lose.  

The Capitol is the big city in the story.  
It tells other places called districts what to do.  

Districts are like small parts of the country.  
There are many districts in the story.  

The Capitol makes the Hunger Games to punish the districts.  
The districts did not listen to the Capitol before.  

Every year, the Capitol chooses one boy and one girl from each district.  
These children are between 12 and 18 years old.  

The Capitol picks the children by a lottery.  
A lottery means a game where the winner is chosen by chance.  

The children who are chosen are called tributes.  
Tributes are young people who take part in the Hunger Games.  

The tributes have to fight each other.  
Only one tribute can live at the end.  

The whole country must watch the Hunger Games on TV.  
People see the fight on their television sets.

This indicates a significant loss of the original core message. Specifically, the original text emphasizes the Hunger Games as a punishment by the Capitol for rebellion, but the writer's output softens this to 'punish the districts because they tried to fight the Capitol,' which slightly changes the political weight and intent. Also, the phrase 'the Capitol is the main city' inaccurately simplifies 'Capitol' from the original text, which is a proper noun referencing the seat of power, not just a 'main city.' Furthermore, the complex concept of a deadly battle is simplified to 'fight each other' without conveying 'only one person can survive' as a brutal survival event with the same explicitness. Although the BERTScore of 0.9151 passes, the meaning loss due to oversimplifications and inaccurate representations causes failure. Although the CEFR classifier rated the text as A2, the vocabulary includes multiple B1-level words such as 'punish,' 'district,' and a missing proper explanation for 'Capitol' causes ambiguity. Also, some sentences such as 'The Capitol is the main city' are awkward and not fully accurate. Suggestion: Maintain the political punishment context explicitly, clarify 'Capitol' as the place of power, and restore the gravity of 'only one person can survive' with simple but precise phrases. Avoid introducing inaccuracies like calling the Capitol merely a city and preserve the original message's intensity.
